To journalister fra Stavanger Aftenblad har truffet de fire mennene og de to kvinnene i fribyen de er blitt tildelt. Captivating meetings with persecuted artists
BOOK: Aftenbladet's reporters have delivered strong stories about what happens when artistic utterances are met with sanctions and punishments.
06 Nov 2019, 15:00 by Ole Kallelid



1 2 3 4 5 6


Jan Zahl and Finn E. V√•ga: Prohibited voices. Documentary. 146 pages. Pelican publishing as.


In the book "Forbidden Voices", the reader meets six people from different countries and continents who have all fled their homeland. By settling in places that are connected to the international network of freebies for pursuing writers and artists, Icorn, they have been able to continue their artistic activities without having to fear being censored, harassed or gagged. The six represent different forms of expression, and among them are writers, journalists, bloggers and musicians.
In exile - and at home
Two journalists from Stavanger Aftenblad have met the four men and the two women in the freebie they have been assigned. The reader becomes acquainted with their life stories by telling the six artists about the background of their escape. These stories are embedded in the stories of journalists' meetings with friends and relatives who remained in Cuba, Bangladesh, Gaza, Sri Lanka, Iran and Turkey respectively. There are various reasons why other artists chose to stay in their home country. While some simply did not want to go into exile, others did not have the opportunity to travel.


Jan Zahl and Finn V√•ga have written and photographed "Forbidden Voices" .üì∑ Kristian Jacobsen

Although there are naturally great differences between the six stories, there are striking many parallels between them. The persecuted writers and artists talk about what it was like to finally feel free from the earlier continuous surveillance by the authorities, but that settling far from home could also bring about social isolation and poor conscience towards those who remained in their home country.


Orlando Luis Pardo Lazo, award-winning Cuban writer, blogger and photographer, thought freely. It did not like the regime in Cuba.üì∑ Finn E. V√•ga

Ethical dilemma
A number of ethical dilemmas are explicitly addressed both in the book and in the newspaper articles and podcasts on which it is based: Should the persecuted writers and artists rather have remained in their home country and fronted their case from there, although it could have meant that they would have been constant in danger? Did the increased attention that came with the free status make it more difficult for relatives, friends and fellow artists at home? Was it unproblematic for the Norwegian journalists who set out to act as tourists and, if necessary, lie about their purpose for the visits?
The meetings with the six freebie artists at their new home and with their relatives in their home countries are vivid and well portrayed by Zahl and V√•ga. The latter, in addition to photographing, has also written two of the texts. The photographer's pictures reinforce the strong and complex emotions that are conveyed in the book with words.


Illustrator and author Mana Neyestani drew a cockroach. As a result, he had to flee from his native Iran.üì∑ Finn E. V√•ga

Captivating insight
A little bit to the end: Authors write in the introduction that there has been a widespread belief that freedom of expression will eventually become the norm throughout the world. This implicitly legitimizes the legitimacy of this book. The reality is, however, in the eyes of most people the opposite, for the right to express oneself is still under pressure. This statement by the authors can at best be characterized as a naive strawman's argument.
This objection does not stem from the fact that Zahl and V√•ga have been able to provide a moving insight into the difficult life situation of six people who, for various reasons, have had to seek refuge in another country. Through words and pictures, readers meet writers and other artists with vastly different backgrounds and life situations, but who have been given the opportunity to continue their business with writing paper and computer in another part of the world.
